DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

Japanese PM Abe reportedly was aware of alterations made to documents in land sale days prior to the public admission, which reports state is fuelling claims by the opposition regarding attempts of a cover up. (Nikkei)
 

UK/EU

UK and EU officials have agreed to take part in "intensive" talks to resolve the issue of the Irish border. (Newswires)
 

FX

USD strengthened with the continual fall of the EUR contributing to the strength of the dollar, leading to the DXY pushing through the 90.000 level. The broad USD strength weighed on precious metals with gold falling over 0.5%, while reports that Mueller had subpoenaed the Trump Organisation prompted some weakness in the USD, although the pressure was relatively short-lived.

EUR was subdued as markets continued to digest the recent comments from ECB members, including Wednesday’s dovish comments from Draghi, while ECB’s Villeroy mentioned that the ECB had made progress on inflation but wouldn’t pre-commit to timing on QE.

GBP was choppy as markets digest various Brexit related comments. Brexit minister Davis said that a transition period would be based on existing arrangements, ahead of next week’s EU Summit. There’s a number of large risk events for the currency next week including the BoE decision, inflation & labour market data, as well as the EU Summit where the UK hopes to agree a transition period.

JPY traded in a relatively tight range but USD/JPY again briefly traded with a 105 handle despite the dollar strength.

NZD Weakened in the wake of GDP data which missed expectations at 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.8%, breaking through the 0.7300 level to the downside. Elsewhere, despite Trump giving Australia an exemption from the tariffs on steel and aluminium, trade war concerns continue to weigh on the AUD which dropped below 0.7800 against the USD.

CHF was little changed following central bank interest rate decision that maintained rates and downgraded inflation expectations.

CAD weakened on the lowest existing home sales figures for 5 years which saw USD/CAD trip stops through the 1.30 level to a 9-month high of 1.3066, finding resistance at a key fib level of 1.3066.

NOK saw a significant move past the 200DMA 9.53 level in EURNOK after the Norges Bank brought forward the timing of possible rate hikes from Autumn 2018 to Summer 2018 (with August or September highlighted). Whilst interest rates remained unchanged this struck a more hawkish tone that displays a confidence in the Scandinavian economy.

Norges Bank Rate Decision 0.50% vs. Exp. 0.50% (Prev. 0.50%)
Norges Bank said it sees rate hike after summer 2018 vs. Prev. after autumn 2018 and stated that the Norwegian economy suggests that it will soon be appropriate to raise the key policy rate. Furthermore, it added that Krone exchange rate is expected to be slightly stronger over the projection period than expected in December. (Newswires)
 

COMMODITIES

US EIA Natural Gas Change (Bcf) -93B vs. Exp. -96B (Prev. -57B). (Newswires)

Iranian oil minister said OPEC is unlikely to change output cutting deal before the end of this year. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICAL

Head of US Pacific Command stated that they have to keep eyes open and can't be too optimistic about summit with North Korea. (Newswires)

US has expanded their cyber-related sanctions against Russia on individuals and entities, while there were also comments from the Russian Deputy Foreign minister that they are preparing retaliatory measures after the US introduced sanctions vs. Russia. (Newswires)

Israel PM Netanyahu has told his cabinet that Trump is to withdraw from the Iran nuclear deal. (Newswires)

Saudi Crown Prince said they will follow suit as soon as possible if Iran develop a nuclear bomb. (Newswires)


US

US Special Counsel Mueller has subpoenaed the Trump Organization demanding documents on Russia. Furthermore, there were also source reports that the Trump Organization has been producing documents to Mueller and Congressional investigations for months, while the White House also said it will continue to cooperate with Special Counsel Mueller but would not comment on Trump Organisation subpoenas. (Newswires)

House Financial Services Committee chair Hensarling said the US House will not pass the Senate bill easing bank rules without more changes. (Newswires)

Mexican Economy Minister Guajardo said must be ready for a NAFTA without the US, while he added that Mexico and Canada can make a deal on their own and that US must decide whether it is in or out. (Newswires)

US NY Fed Manufacturing (Mar) 22.50 vs. Exp. 15.00 (Prev. 13.10). (Newswires)
US Export Prices MM (Feb) 0.2% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.8%)
US Import Prices MM (Feb) 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 1.0%, Rev. 0.8%)


MARKET RECAP

Equity Futures traded slightly upwards with no fundamental catalyst to be found by midday trading. A slight downtick was later observed on the news that Special Counsel Mueller had subpoenaed the Trump organisation seeking Russia documents, which dented risk sentiment, while reports that Walmart had issued misleading e-commerce results gave further impetus to the downtick. SPX -0.08% at 2747, DJI +0.45% at 24873, NDX -0.14% at 7030.

Bear flattening was observed with the short-end underperforming in the curve. A bid was later observed after the Mueller subpoena news hit the wires, but overall volumes were relatively light and liquidity thin which IFR noted could be the trend leading up to the Fed rate decision on Wednesday. 10yr T-note futures (June 2018) settled down 1.5 ticks at 120.60.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: DXY nudging 90.000 again
content: The Dollar has emerged as the pm session outperformer and broad gainer vs most G10 counterparts bar the safe haven Jpy (still pivoting around 106.00) and Brexit boosted Gbp (Cable back up near 1.4000, and Eur/Gbp easing towards 0.8800) after more reports that a transition deal between the UK and EU is close at hand. Usd/Cad has hit fresh 2018 highs above 1.3000 (circa 1.3045) with additional impetus to flog the Loonie coming from very weak Canadian housing data (that overshadowed a firmer ADP read, which itself has been upstaged by last Friday’s official jobs report) and remarks from the Mexican Economy Minister regarding NAFTA (basically saying that the US can be left out of the trade accord). Next bullish target for Usd/Cad is a Fib at 1.3066 before 1.3100, while Usd/Mxn is looking firmer above 18.5000 and its 200 DMA. The Aud and Nzd also extended losses vs the Greenback amidst more inflammatory remarks between the US and China on protectionist policies and with the Kiwi still feeling the adverse effects of NZ’s GDP data miss overnight – Aud/Usd edging closer to 0.7800 and Nzd/Usd back below 0.7300. Note, the US admin also extended/expanded sanctions vs Russia after the UK on Wednesday and Russia plans to retaliate as it has to the UK – Usd/Rub rallying as a result. Eur/Usd still relatively steady despite slipping to around 1.2325 at one stage, and perhaps finding some option expiry-related support as 1 bn ran-off between 1.2335-50. Usd/Chf and Eur/Chf remained elevated, and the former inched a bit closer to 0.9500 again on latest Franc highly overvalued assessments from the SNB, but the Nok only lost some of its hawkish Norges Bank momentum to trade back at 9.5000+ vs the Eur (only just) after Governor Olson said only 1 hike is likely this year. In terms of the DXY, January TICS flows ahead, while the Eur may get some impetus from ECB’s Lautenschlaeger, the Aud via RBA Deputy Governor Debelle and Nzd from Manufacturing PMI.

DAILY US OPENING NEWS: European equities are trading relatively mixed (Eurostoxx 50 +0.2%) with IBEX and SMI underperforming
content:
15th March 2018

  • European equities are trading relatively mixed (Eurostoxx 50 +0.2%) with IBEX and SMI underperforming
  • Norges Bank brings forward its rate hike forecast
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Jobless Claims and comments from ECB’s Lautenschlaeger

ASIA

Asia stocks were mixed as sentiment partially improved from the early rout seen after the S&P 500 and DJIA posted a 3rd consecutive day of losses due to ongoing trade war concerns and disappointing Retail Sales data. ASX 200 (-0.2%) was led lower by weakness in the financials and energy sectors, while Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) was choppy with initial underperformance seen on JPY strength and as political woes continued to cloud over Japan with former tax chief Sagawa to possibly testify as soon as next week on the cronyism/land sale scandal. However, resilience was later seen across the regional bourses and the Japanese benchmark then pared all its losses. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (flat) were also indecisive and swung between gains and losses as participants mulled over President Trump’s pick of free-trade advocate Larry Kudlow for his top economic adviser role, which is seen to be a more favourable scenario for China in comparison than other hardliner candidates, although Kudlow had already stepped up his rhetoric on China in his first interview since being chosen for the job. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat with only minimal support seen amid the dampened global risk appetite while a mixed 20yr auction result also added to the non-committal tone.

PBoC injected CNY 20bln via 7-day reverse repos and CNY 20bln via 28-day reverse repos. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3141 (Prev. 6.3205)

New Zealand GDP (Q4) Q/Q 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.8% (Prev. 0.6%). (Newswires)

New Zealand GDP (Q4) Y/Y 2.9% vs. Exp. 3.1% (Prev. 2.7%)

CENTRAL BANKS

Norges Bank Rate Decision 0.50% vs. Exp. 0.50% (Prev. 0.50%)

-Sees rate hike after summer 2018, Prev. autumn 2018

-Norwegian economy suggests that it will soon be appropriate to raise the key policy rate, sees somewhat earlier rate hikes than seen in the December report.

-Krone exchange rate expected to be slightly stronger over the projection period than expected in December

 

Norges Bank Governor Olsen said it’s hard to tell whether rate hike would come in August or September. (Newswires)

SNB Interest Rate Decision -0.75% vs. Exp. -0.75% (Prev. -0.75%)

-Swiss Franc remains highly valued

-Will remain active in FX markets

-Negative interest rate remains essential, along with FX intervention when required

 

ECB's Villeroy says there is robust recovery and progress on inflation, adds very little debate on outlook at the ECB and will not pre-commit regarding timing of end to asset purchases. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

New NEC Director Larry Kudlow commented that he would like to see the USD slightly stronger than it currently is, and that he would buy USD and sell gold. (Newswires)

US President Trump’s lawyers are to prepare for an interview with Special Counsel Mueller, according to sources. (Politico)

US Senate voted 67 to 21 in favour of the bill to roll back parts of Dodd-Frank Act and ease regulations for banks. (Newswires)

Canadian PM Trudeau said he is confident on reaching a NAFTA agreement and that Canada is happy to speed up NAFTA discussions if required. (Newswires)

According to reports in the Times, EU negotiators have accepted the UK’s demands that it should be able to pursue an independent trade policy while remaining inside the customs union and single market. Elsewhere, Brexit Minister David Davis has signalled that he is prepared to accept a shorter transition period than the UK wanted. (The Times/Press Association)

Italy's League leader Salvini and 5-Star leader Di Maio discussed options. (Newswires)

 

EQUITIES

European equities are trading relatively mixed (Eurostoxx 50 +0.2%) with IBEX and SMI underperforming. Focus has been on the insurance sector this morning with strong guidance for Munrich Re lifting shares this morning, while firm financial results from Generali have also supported the sector. Elsewhere, SocGen are among the underperformers after the unexpected departure of the Deputy CEO.

FX

Aside from the usual suspects (global trade wars and President Trump’s White House staff reshuffling), 2 Central Bank policy meetings were in focus, and while the SNB trimmed its inflation forecasts virtually everything else remained unchanged from the previous quarterly assessment. Hence, Eur/Chf was essentially static and rangebound between 1.1680-1.1700, while Usd/Chf held within a 0.9460-35 range despite broader Usd weakness (Usd/Jpy sub-106.00 and DXY still under 90.000). However, the Norges Bank more than lived up to hawkish expectations by bringing forward its hike forecast to after Summer from after Autumn in December, and more precisely August or September, according to Governor Olsen. 2018 non-oil GDP is now seen at 2.6% vs 2.3%, and the output gap closing quicker, so inflation also to target sooner (now 2% vs 2.5% prior to March 2nd). Eur/Nok duly dumped, albeit somewhat belatedly, through the 200DMA at 9.5300, then bids at 9.5000 and down to around 9.4746. Elsewhere, Eur/Usd was rangy from 1.2350-85, while Aud/Usd and Nzd/Usd are softer after the former failed to sustain 0.7900+ levels on Wednesday and following weaker than anticipated NZ GDP data overnight. Conversely, Cable fell quite sharply and abruptly, with Eur/Gbp rallying around the same time on nothing obvious, so perhaps order/flow/stop-related rather than fundamental. 

FIXED INCOME

Compared to the hectic action in FX, debt futures remain relatively dull, but there has been some range extension and further deviation. Indeed, Bunds are having another look at 158.00 after topping out just ahead on Wednesday and the next bullish objective is 158.19 vs 158.09 at best so far (+15 ticks vs -13 ticks at the Eurex low). However, Gilts are still lagging despite a solid if not stellar DMO auction, though have just climbed into positive territory at 121.99 (+4 ticks vs -22 ticks at worst) and could test resistance just above 122.00. Elsewhere, UST futures remain firm following disappointing retail sales data against the backdrop of trade/protectionism policy wars.  

COMMODITIES

In the commodity complex, crude futures trade relatively flat with WTI trading just south of the USD 61/bbl mark. Additionally, the IEA published their monthly oil report and much like yesterday’s OPEC report, they revised higher demand forecasts, but did maintain non-OPEC supply forecasts.

Iranian oil minister says OPEC is unlikely to change output cutting deal before the end of this year. (Newswires)

subject: Bunds: softer start despite neutral leads from USTs

However, the downside looks contained in the current broadly risk-off mood amidst heightened concerns over global trade wars and ahead of what looks destined to be an interesting if not somewhat heated G20 gathering next week. Prior to that, more supply to digest and this time from Spain and the Eurozone core via France, which also provides today’s main regional data in the form of CPI, albeit the final readings. Speaker-wise, ECB’s Lautenschlaeger in the pm session after a raft of US data.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS: Highlights include stories from BHP, BT, Vivendi and Credit Suisse
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

15th March 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0200CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0215CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0215CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia stocks were mixed as sentiment partially improved from the early rout seen after the S&P 500 and DJIA posted a 3rd consecutive day of losses due to ongoing trade war concerns and disappointing Retail Sales data. ASX 200 (-0.2%) was led lower by weakness in the financials and energy sectors, while Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) was choppy with initial underperformance seen on JPY strength and as political woes continued to cloud over Japan with former tax chief Sagawa to possibly testify as soon as next week on the cronyism/land sale scandal. However, resilience was later seen across the regional bourses and the Japanese benchmark then pared all its losses. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.5%) were also indecisive and swung between gains and losses as participants mulled over President Trump’s pick of free-trade advocate Larry Kudlow for his top economic adviser role, which is seen to be a more favourable scenario for China in comparison than other hardliner candidates, although Kudlow had already stepped up his rhetoric on China in his first interview since being chosen for the job.

FTSE

BHP (BLT LN) – The world’s largest copper mine Escondida in Chile invited worker unions on Wednesday to begin early talks on a new collective labour contract. (Newswires)

Persimmon (PSN LN) – Co to appoint new chairman Roger Devlin on Thursday, aiming to put a huge executive pay row behind it. (Newswires)

BT Group (BT/A LN) – Co. is closing in on an agreement with union leaders to shut its final salary suspension and move workers to a defined contribution scheme to tackle its funding deficit. (Newswires)

Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA LN) – Co. is close to reaching a deal over liquified natural gas supply in Hong Kong, beating major competitors and to be the first one to provide LNG to the area. (Newswires)

Ex-dividends - Anglo American (AAL LN) and Hammerson (HMSO LN) will trade without entitlement to their latest dividend pay-out on Thursday, trimming 1.37 points off the FTSE 100. (Newswires)BROKER MOVES

DAX

Lufthansa (LHA GY) – 2017 revenue EUR 35.58bln vs. Exp. EUR 35.5bln. 2017 adj. EBIT EUR 2.97bln vs. Exp. EUR 2.838bln. Q4 adj. EBIT EUR 413mln vs. Exp. 278mln. Co. to propose 2017 dividend of EUR 0.80/shr vs. EUR 0.71/shr. Co. expects 2018 adj EBIT slightly below 2017 level. Co. says organic capacity to increase 7% in 2018. Co. sees unit revenues broadly stable in 2018. (Newswires)

BASF (BAS GY) – Co. will devote EUR 2.7bln to the Asia-Pacific region through 2022, with Sanjeev Gandhi in charge of the region. (Nikkei)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Lanxess (LXS GY) – 2017 sales +25.5% at EUR 9.664bln. 2017 EBITDA pre exceptionals +30% at EUR 1.290bln. 2017 net income pre exceptionals +54% at EUR 379mln. Reported profit down 55% at 87mln. Proposes dividend for 2017 of EUR 0.80/shr, +14% Y/Y. Co. sees slight rise in 2018 EBITDA. CEO said Warren Buffett is said to be a long-term investor. (Newswires)

K+S (SDF GY) – 2017 revenue EUR 3.6bln vs. Prev. EUR 3.5bln. 2017 EBIT EUR 271mln vs. Prev. EUR 229mln. Co. intends to propose dividend of EUR 0.35/shr. Co.’s outlook for 2018 shows revenue and EBITDA will continue to grow. Indebtedness will fall. Co. estimates revenue will be tangibly higher and expects to see a significant improvement in free cash flow in  2018. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

CAC

Vivendi (VIV FP) – Co. is committed to supporting Telecom Italia’s (TIT IM) growth. Co. believes Telecom Italia’s new business plan is an ambitious and a realistic strategy to accelerate group’s financial performance. Co. adds Elliott’s strategy is probably aimed at dismantling Telecom Italia. Co. CEO is considering suspending his executive functions at Telecom Italia while strategic debates are going on; according to spokesman. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

PAN-EUROPE

Tech names - EU is reportedly preparing unprecedented continent-wide regulations against search engines and has drafted proposals for a digital tax on tech giants' EU turnover which will raise EUR 5bln annually. (FT/Twitter)

Auto names – MPs urge UK ban on the sale of new diesel and petrol cars. (Newswires)

Leonardo (LDO IM) – 2017 revenue EUR 11.5bln vs. Exp. EUR 11.6bln. 2017 EBITA EUR 1.07bln. Co. to propose dividend EUR 0.14/shr. Co. confirms 2018 guidance. (Newswires)

Generali (G IM) – 2017 net profit EUR 2.11bln vs. Exp. EUR 1.968bln. 2017 operating profit EUR 4.89bln vs. EUR 4.857bln. Co. proposes 2017 dividend of EUR 0.85/shr vs. Prev. EUR 0.80/shr. CEO says group perfectly positioned to reach all 2018 targets. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

SMI

Credit Suisse (CSGN SW) – The co. was sued on Wednesday by an American investor over misstatements about a complex product betting on stock market swings let to losses for those who bought in at inflated prices. (Newswires)

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

SCANDINAVIA

BROKER MOVES

US

* EQUITIES: SPX -0.56% at 2750, DJI -1.00% at 24760, NDX -0.08% at 7041

 

* SECTORS: CONS DISC (XLY): -0.20%, CONS STAP (XLP): -1.26%, ENERGY (XLE): -0.64%, FINANCIALS (XLF): -1.19%, HEALTH CARE (XLV): -0.58%, INDUSTRIALS (XLI): -1.12%, MATERIALS (XLB): -1.31%, TECH (XLK): -0.07%, TELECOMS (XTL): -0.76%, UTILITIES (XLU): +0.98%

* After February's retail sales and PPI data -- which showed retail sales remaining subdued, and real consumption slowing in Q1; while PPI continued to firm, signalling inflation pressures in the pipeline -- US equity futures dipped slightly. The net impact was that the 'Goldilocks' narrative remained intact, allowing stocks to move higher at the cash open. However, trade concerns continue to linger, and weighed on risk-assets after the open, sending equities lower. There was a little bounce in afternoon trade on news that Larry Kudlow had been offered the NEC chair job to replace Cohn, with stocks later finding a springboard from the 50dma at 2747 as news broke that Kudlow was said to accept the role.

US Senate voted 67 to 21 in favour of the bill to roll back parts of Dodd-Frank Act and ease regulations for banks. (Newswires)

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian bourses traded in somewhat mixed fashion as trade war concerns continue to linger, NZD slips after softer than expected GDP figures.
content:
15th March 2018

  • Asian bourses traded in somewhat mixed fashion as trade war concerns continue to linger.
  • NZD slips after softer than expected GDP figures.
  • Looking ahead, highlights include monetary policy decisions from the Norges Bank and SNB, US Jobless Claims and comments from ECB’s Lautenschlaeger.

 

ASIA

Asia stocks were mixed as sentiment partially improved from the early rout seen after the S&P 500 and DJIA posted a 3rd consecutive day of losses due to ongoing trade war concerns and disappointing Retail Sales data. ASX 200 (-0.2%) was led lower by weakness in the financials and energy sectors, while Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) was choppy with initial underperformance seen on JPY strength and as political woes continued to cloud over Japan with former tax chief Sagawa to possibly testify as soon as next week on the cronyism/land sale scandal. However, resilience was later seen across the regional bourses and the Japanese benchmark then pared all its losses. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.5%) were also indecisive and swung between gains and losses as participants mulled over President Trump’s pick of free-trade advocate Larry Kudlow for his top economic adviser role, which is seen to be a more favourable scenario for China in comparison than other hardliner candidates, although Kudlow had already stepped up his rhetoric on China in his first interview since being chosen for the job. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat with only minimal support seen amid the dampened global risk appetite while a mixed 20yr auction result also added to the non-committal tone. 

PBoC injected CNY 20bln via 7-day reverse repos and CNY 20bln via 28-day reverse repos. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3141 (Prev. 6.3205)

UK/EU

EU is reportedly preparing unprecedented continent-wide regulations against search engines and has drafted proposals for a digital tax on tech giants' EU turnover which will raise EUR 5bln annually. (FT/Twitter)

According to reports in the Times, EU negotiators have accepted the UK’s demands that it should be able to pursue an independent trade policy while remaining inside the customs union and single market. Elsewhere, Brexit Minister David Davis has signalled that he is prepared to accept a shorter transition period than the UK wanted. (The Times/Press Association)

FX

In FX markets, DXY remained lacklustre and below the 90.00 level amid ongoing US-China trade tensions, which marginally benefitted its major counterparts on what was a relatively uneventful session for currencies. Elsewhere, the subdued greenback and safe-haven flows into JPY pressured USD/JPY below the 106.00 handle and saw similar weakness in JPY-crosses, while NZD/USD was choppy with initial pressure seen after New Zealand GDP data missed expectations, before the pair later recovered on the back of a softer USD.

New Zealand GDP (Q4) Q/Q 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.8% (Prev. 0.6%). (Newswires)
New Zealand GDP (Q4) Y/Y 2.9% vs. Exp. 3.1% (Prev. 2.7%)

Canadian PM Trudeau said he is confident on reaching a NAFTA agreement and that Canada is happy to speed up NAFTA discussions if required. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were range-bound in which WTI crude futures just about held above the USD 61/bbl level, with overnight price action muted after yesterday’s mild swings in which participants digested a larger than expected build to headline DoE crude inventories with significant drawdowns to gasoline and distillate stockpiles. Elsewhere, gold was saw marginal gains amid the backdrop of a lacklustre greenback and downbeat risk tone which also kept copper steady. 

US

Bull-flattening along the curve was the theme again, with shorted yields slightly positive, and the long-end rallied by around 4bps. Major curves were mixed; the 2s5s was c.1bps narrower, 2s30s flat, 5s30s flat, and the 5s10s was wider by c.2bps. 10yr T-note futures (June 2018) settled 7 ticks higher at 120-17+.

US President Trump picked Larry Kudlow for the NEC Director role which Kudlow accepted. Larry Kudlow later commented that he would like to see the USD slightly stronger than it currently is, and that he would buy USD and sell gold. Furthermore, Kudlow also stated that the EU could get carve outs if it negotiates with the US and that China has not played by the rules on trade for a long time. (Newswires)

US Senate voted 67 to 21 in favour of the bill to roll back parts of Dodd-Frank Act and ease regulations for banks. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia traded indecisive and partially recovered from initial rout
content: Asia stocks were mixed as sentiment partially improved from the early rout seen after the S&P 500 and DJIA posted a 3rd consecutive day of losses due to ongoing trade war concerns and disappointing Retail Sales data. ASX 200 (-0.2%) was led lower by weakness in the financials and energy sectors, while Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) was choppy with initial underperformance seen on JPY strength and as political woes continued to cloud over Japan with former tax chief Sagawa to possibly testify as soon as next week on the cronyism/land sale scandal. However, resilience was later seen across the regional bourses and the Japanese benchmark then pared all its losses. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.5%) were also indecisive and swung between gains and losses as participants mulled over President Trump’s pick of free-trade advocate Larry Kudlow for his top economic adviser role, which is seen to be a more favourable scenario for China in comparison than other hardliner candidates, although Kudlow had already stepped up his rhetoric on China in his first interview since being chosen for the job. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat with only minimal support seen amid the dampened global risk appetite while a mixed 20yr auction result also added to the non-committal tone.

subject: EU is reportedly preparing unprecedented continent-wide regulations against search engines, according to Twitter reports
ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia mirrors the rout across global stocks
content:
Asia stocks are mostly lower as region mirrors the rout seen on Wall St. where the S&P 500 and DJIA posted a 3rd consecutive day of losses amid ongoing trade war concerns and disappointing Retail Sales data. ASX 200 (-0.1%) has been led lower by continued weakness in financials and energy sectors, while Nikkei 225 (-0.5%) is pressured by JPY strength and as political woes continue to cloud over Japan with former tax chief Sagawa to possibly testify as soon as next week on the cronyism/government land sale scandal. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) are also in the red, although losses are contained amid outperformance in Shenzhen and with some also suggesting that free-trade advocate Larry Kudlow’s appointment as the new National Economic Council Director to be a more favourable scenario for China in comparison than other touted hardliner candidates, despite Kudlow already stepping up his rhetoric on China in his first interview since being chosen for the job.

In FX markets, DXY remains lacklustre and below the 90.00 level amid ongoing US-China trade tensions, which has marginally benefitted its major counterparts on what has been a relatively uneventful session so far for currencies. Elsewhere, the subdued greenback and safe-haven flows into JPY pressured USD/JPY below the 106.00 handle and saw similar weakness in JPY-crosses, while NZD/USD was choppy with initial pressure seen after New Zealand GDP data missed expectations, before the pair later recovered on the back of a softer USD.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are flat with only marginal support seen from the dampened global risk appetite and with demand lacking as participants await today’s 20yr auction.
